text.p: True or False: If [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is a subspace of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline], and both [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] are infinite-dimensional, then [mathjaxinline]W=V[/mathjaxinline].

font.p: False. The proposition does not apply to infinite-dimensional spaces. For instance, if [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] is the vector space of all functions on [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is the space of polynomials [mathjaxinline]\mathbb {P}[/mathjaxinline] (which is a subspace of the space of all functions), then both [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] are infinite-dimensional, but [mathjaxinline]W\ne V[/mathjaxinline].
